This text was transcribed using whisper model: large-v2

 Well, hello, everyone. Good afternoon. Perhaps good evening for some. It's good morning for
me still. Pleasure, though, to be here for virtual ZivCon. Not as nice as being in Gdynia,
but we will take what we can get given current circumstances. So for to close out the day
for ZivCon, we'll talk about something that I've been thinking about for almost exactly
a year now. Cyber consequences in the perspective of operational dependencies and how this applies
to security beyond the scope that we typically apply of just networks or just focusing on
the IT assets within an organization. So first, who am I? My name is Joseph Słowik. If you
actually pronounce it properly in Polish as opposed to how pronounce it in the United
States. But currently, I work for a company called Drigos, where I do threat intelligence
work with an emphasis on industrial control systems. And in fact, many of the examples
that we'll talk about today are industrial in nature, which will be fairly obvious why
that is when you start talking about chains of consequences and how that plays out in
terms of physical responses. And also, prior to that, I led the incident response team
at Los Alamos National Laboratory and was a officer in the U.S. Navy prior to that.
But enough about me. Really, this talk came about with an event that happened exactly
a year ago today. Maybe the 13th of September, depending on time zones, but at least it was
reported in the U.S. press on the 14th of September last year in 2019 of a drone and
missile strike on a oil and gas facility or several oil and gas facilities in Saudi Arabia,
including a massive oil processing facility at a location called Abqaiq, which is responsible
for hydro desulphurization of sour crude oil. Essentially, the Abqaiq facility allows
for the further refinement of produced crude oil so that it is acceptable to markets for
importation. Now, if you look at the overall strategic picture within Saudi Arabia, the
Abqaiq facility has been sort of the nasty little secret of the Saudi oil industry for
quite some time in that the majority of Saudi oil exportation is dependent upon the refinement
at Abqaiq in order for oil to be suitable for exportation. Basically, if that facility
doesn't exist or if that facility is damaged, such as through a drone or missile strike,
the entire industry grinds to a halt. And in fact, that's kind of what happened for
several weeks, if not several months, as that facility was being repaired that the Saudis
needed, or at least Saudi Aramco had to dip into reserves in order to meet previous demand.
So that really shows that there's a sort of a critical dependency here that in order to
impact a much bigger process, the entire oil and gas industry in Saudi Arabia, really you
can target only one specific facility and even then only very specific aspects of that facility
in order to have outsized results. Now, you may be asking yourself right now,
wait a minute, this is a cyber conference. This is red versus blue. We should be talking
about information security. Where the hell's the cyber? Well, the cyber is there because
concurrently with this event, roughly concurrently, certainly from late 2018 through multiple events
in 2019, including a few that took place shortly after the physical attack on the Abqaiq facility,
that there had been multiple rounds of disruptive malware attacks or incidents
on the oil and gas sector in Saudi Arabia, as well as in other areas of the Gulf.
So really what we're seeing, or how we can categorize the Abqaiq strike really is one
part of a broader set of efforts or designs to try and disrupt one of the main economic engines
of this region and as efforts tied to Iranian strategic interests. So what we're seeing is not
just a example of what cyber can do, but really looking in to a greater degree or to a more in
depth degree of adversaries have goals and those goals don't necessarily need to be met by cyber,
but the way in which modern systems and complex nature of things like the Saudi oil and gas
industry operate mean that we can start looking at really specific ways of targeting these
establishments or these organizations so that relatively small or focused impacts can have
outsized influence resulting in much broader dislocation than just the immediate impact of
whatever is initially targeted. And looking at some of the wiper events, we haven't quite gotten
there yet, but in light of things like the Abqaiq strike, it seems that adversaries are
starting to get smarter in terms of what they're targeting and what certain weaknesses or Achilles
heels may exist within these entities. So the takeaway is that attackers ultimately care about
causing disruption of some sort and complex systems like a nationwide oil and gas industry
largely operated by a single organization really yield specific pain points that can allow for
outsized impact if those weak points are first identified and then exploited or disrupted in
some way, which gets us back to the cybers. So our agenda today after this lengthy introduction
is we'll talk about process and operational dependencies and how this loops back into
information systems, and then look at in very brief fashion, some targeted disruptive attacks
that focus on this concept of dependencies or critical path dependencies for how things are
executed and what sort of implications and risks those dependencies have. And then we'll conclude
by talking about what do we do about this? How do we defend against this? And how can we embrace or
take into consideration concepts like offensive security in trying to cover or to mitigate against
these type of risks? And finally close with some future expectations for what we might expect
within this space. So first process complexity. This is a screenshot from modeling software
produced by Rockwell. It's called Arena. At least I think it's still produced by Rockwell. But
you know, this is just a very simple example of how to model a complex, in this case, it's a
shipping process. And as we can see here, and this is no different than looking at things like program
UML or, you know, process to program design language of how we can start laying out operations
from the very start or inputs into a process all the way to its end and seeing the different
decision gates or the different requirements as, you know, whether you're talking about
manufacturing as widgets move along the line of the different necessary stages that the widget
needs to go through until it is finalized or production is complete. Well, the thing is,
is that process complexity means that we have an ever greater number of potential touch points
where that process can be disrupted. That if a certain process node is removed or degraded in
some way, the entire process as a whole can grind to a halt, which gets us into the concept of
process dependencies. So typically we look at these in terms of critical path nodes as they
come in terms of timing. That, you know, the sort of deltas or the differences between the earliest
and latest start and finish times for something and how that gets sorted out to identify what are
the stages that will be the determining items for how long a process will take. Well, the same sort
of concept applies when we start looking again, going back to process complexity, that if we have
something like a hydro desulphurization facility that is required for oil and gas production,
that that becomes a critical path node for the entire process to function. So while there may
be certain things that, yes, if this is delayed or degraded in some way, we can work around that in
some way, or the amount of time required to bring that specific piece of the process back up and
running again is something that we can absorb because we're waiting on other things to get
taken care of in the meantime. There are other items that we simply can't do without that form
a critical path node for the overall process that if those are disrupted, then the entire process
is impacted in some fashion. And we see this building up as we get into ever more complex and
ever more distributed sort of processes that have multiple dependencies. These can be dependencies
on external suppliers, they can be dependencies on external infrastructure, think the cloud,
which we'll get into in a second, and other items that can allow for operational disruption to be
simplified. I mean, it's kind of funny that we talk about greater complexity on the one hand,
leading to a simplification of cyber attacks or even just attacks in general on the other.
But the ultimate takeaway from this is that in order to adequately defend or build in resiliency
to these sorts of networks, whether we're talking about industrial processes or even things like
elections or the financial system, we need to understand the nature of the operation and what
those critical path nodes are or what those most important or most significant aspects
of the overall process might be that can lead to outsized impacts should an attacker
hold that at risk. And we see this in modern operations through things like
complex supply chains, as well as an emphasis from a business perspective of things like just
in time production, and inventory minimization, the so called Toyota production system or
method of thinking that many organizations, whether you're talking logistics, like an Amazon,
or manufacturing, like a Toyota, or most other automotive manufacturers, of not having lots of
spare parts on hand, because it costs money, and we want to save money and make things as most
efficient as possible. Well, the problem is in getting after these efficiencies or trying to
diversify supply chains is that it starts extending out the potentials for disrupting
the process itself and introducing the capability or enhancing the capability of an attacker to
hold that at risk. And we see this extending into digitalization, whether we're talking about
something within industrial controls, like the so called fourth industrial revolution, where we start
integrating things like cloud computing and increased adoption of information systems and
physical environments, such that items that previously would have been only vulnerable or
only accessible through physical means or some other fashion are now network reachable, allowing
for attackers to potentially influence processes or touch or manipulate processes that wouldn't
have been accessible previously, exposing the vulnerable or the critical systems to potential
attack. And we see this even getting away from very industrial examples into just general information
processing, where we talk about organizations minimizing risks through adoption of the cloud
or adoption of managed service providers. But as we've seen, when things like a cloud flare goes
down, or there's a massive power outage or network, whether physical or logical network routing
incident that might impact the northern Virginia region in the United States, which happens to be
where the EC2 instance for AWS East is located, that that has magnified effects that then all
those organizations that were dependent upon those resources are now impacted because they had
relied upon that being there no matter what, and now are impacted through the loss of that
supposed resiliency that had been built out through a third party.
Okay, so that's enough about talking, you know, lots of business examples and other sorts of
things. Maybe it's a little boring for those who are just closing up the day of multiple talks.
How does this actually apply to attacks? And I always like throwing the Norse map out here,
because we can all point and laugh at this, because they're no longer around to defend
themselves. But anyway, you know, have we actually seen this in practice? And the answer is yes. And
not just in talking about someone launching missiles at an oil and gas processing facility.
We've seen this going back quite far. And to try to limit the discussion, I'm only going to talk
about about five or six examples today. But the first one goes back six years. In Ukraine, in 2014,
during the country's presidential elections, there were a series of network intrusions
linked to cyber Berkut, which is assessed by many to be linked to Russian strategic interests.
You can actually read about that in depth in a site mentioned earlier, with Tom Ridd's book that
it comes up in there. But anyway, getting back to the Ukraine example, what was interesting about
this is that the defenders in question did a good job in remediating and recovering from this attack,
that it looked like the attackers were trying to take down various election infrastructure and
inhibit the ability of the Ukrainian state to announce results and to provide feedback in the
aftermath of the election. Well, the thing is, though, is that there was a critical dependency
that the immediate defenders didn't have control over, which provided for a very interesting attack
pattern. And while this didn't exactly work as intended, because the defenders in Ukraine did
a good job in responding to the initial attacks, what this event highlighted was a really interesting
way in which the media served as a critical external dependency for the Ukrainian election
results, such that the way the attack was designed was to try to interrupt the ability of
the Ukrainian government to broadcast official results, and then to throw up fake results that
could then be amplified, retweeted, however you want to phrase it, by malicious authorities, and
in this case by Russian state media, in order to increase uncertainty and cause a certain degree
of instability surrounding the entire electoral process. And the thing is, is that as good of a
job as the defenders did in defending the election authority networks, they didn't have control over
this media aspect, and had this attack been a shade more successful, the attackers would have been,
or the defenders would have been, in a bind in not being able to, or not having the foresight to
extend their response to include things like, oh, you know, do we have the ability to try to control
or manage the narrative for what is going on, and how results may be broadcast after the fact,
and might an attacker take advantage of this? Keeping on the Ukrainian theme, the very next year
in 2015, we saw the first cyber nexus, or the first publicly known, at least, cyber nexus
manipulation of the electric system, with an attack linked to the sand worm entity
that resulted in the disruption of electric distribution operations across several sites
within Ukraine for several hours. What was interesting about this attack, though, is that it
wasn't just a question of turning off the lights, so to speak, but rather it was a attack that went
to pains to target process recovery, looking at the specific functions within the electric
electricity management, or the, especially on the distribution level, managing the distribution
yards of what would the operators need to restore operations after opening breakers within the
affected facilities. So really the electric disruption was just the first stage of a
multi-stage attack that included afterwards blocking serial to internet converters that
would allow for logical commands from the control center to go down to the switching yards by
basically bricking those devices to prevent communication. And then, to make things even
worse, corrupting the uninterruptible power supplies within the control rooms so that the
backup power, when primary power was lost because of the electric disruption, backup power was also
lost. And then finally wiping the operator workstations with kill disk malware to produce a
loss of view over the environment in addition to the loss of power and the inability to send
commands to the physical equipment. So overall, what the attackers realized or attempted to achieve
in 2015 was not just interrupting the supply of power, but sort of blowing the bridges behind them
by understanding the processes necessary in order to facilitate operational recovery to prolong
that disruption as long as possible. Well, in this case, the Ukrainians, and again, the Ukraine
has been the victim of so many things, and overall they've done a really good job in trying to
keep pace with these under very, very distressing circumstances, not to mention having
a portion of their country basically invaded. But in 2015, the operators were able to restore
electricity fairly quickly because they rapidly transitioned into manual operations
so that they avoided all of the dislocation produced by these recovery targeting aspects
of the attack. If it happened in Western Europe or if this had happened in the United States
or Poland, for that matter, and parts of the electric system that I'm familiar with that are
rapidly modernizing, this attack would have been far more disruptive because there's a greater
reliance on having remote connectivity and remote control over these facilities, whereas the
Ukrainians were able to spin up personnel on site quite quickly to restore operations.
But what's interesting is that in 2016, again in Ukraine, we had another power event that
indicated, at least after some further analysis, that attackers had taken into consideration. So
the initial takeaway from 2016 in Ukraine was malware that was responsible for manipulating
the electric system. Indestroyer, as named by ESET, Crash Override, as named by Dregos,
this resulted in a slightly smaller electric disruption with a quicker recovery time. And so
at first it seemed like this attack might be less severe, but further review indicated actually a
much more significant attack that was looking at process protection and specifically the
criticality of protective relays as a critical component in ensuring the safety and protection
of electrical equipment to try to induce an actual destructive attack within the
targeted transmission station. Because in this attack, it looked like the attackers anticipated
the rush to physical restoration because after inducing the transmission outage, the attackers
then basically deployed somewhat similar techniques in order to disrupt recovery,
but in this case, added on an additional stage to this attack by executing a denial of service
on a digital protective relay within the environment that removed line protection
from the electric system. Such that once the if the system had been reconnected with the denial
of service having taken place, then the system would have been in an unprotected state on
restoration leading to the possibility of things like either an overcurrent condition or the
possibility that natural fluctuations within the overall electric environment could propagate
beyond the process protection in place to cause physical damage to the electrical equipment at
the transmission station, which would have been a much costlier or a much more significant attack.
Fortunately, the attackers screwed a lot of things up in this attack. There was a paper that I wrote
on this, if anyone is interested in diving into this in some detail, it's also included in the
references at the end of this talk. But overall, the takeaway from this is that the attackers are
learning from events over time and getting more aggressive and more ambitious in what it is
they're trying to targeting by looking at focal points within the overall system and identifying
what are those critical touch points that could allow for maximization of not just disruption,
but in the 2016 Ukraine example, even potentially physical destruction as well.
Moving on to Saudi Arabia, we had the Triton crisis event, which was an oil and gas facility
within Saudi Arabia. So it might sound very similar to the Abqaiq attack, although
this is more likely linked to Russian state interest than it is Iran. That's kind of an open
question and really beside the point for what we're discussing here. But what was interesting about
this industrial focused attack was this was a safety specific attack that the attackers realized
that in order to try to disrupt operations within an oil and gas facility, they needed to pair
an intrusion into the plant distributed control system network that controls the physical process
itself within the oil and gas facility with a compromise of the plant's safety network as well.
This led to the Triton crisis malware, which enabled a undetected arbitrary modification
of safety setting and work properly. The takeaway here is that the malware didn't work, which
resulted in the safety system tripping. So it led to an immediate plant shutdown instead of
putting the plant in an unsafe state, leading to the potential for causing physical disruption
later on. The main takeaway here though, is that even though the attackers again
failed to try to execute the attack as likely intended, and there's a couple of papers I've
linked at the end of this presentation that go into this in further detail.
This also shows that attackers are understanding the interconnected nature of certain industrial
processes that in order to have a cyber focused impact on a oil and gas environment, that it's not
sufficient to just modify the settings within the production network because those changes or any
sort of consequences from them will be caught by things like the plant safety network, or the
various safety instrumented systems that are deployed as part of the plant setup. So instead,
you need to target that safety network in order to remove that layer of protection to allow attacks
to propagate beyond where they would be caught and potentially mitigated by plant safety systems.
In order to enable a potential destructive attack. So I've picked on Ukraine a lot,
we've talked about Saudi Arabia, but these aren't just events that are limited to places that may be
somewhat similar to active conflict zones. Instead, we're actually seeing this in places
like the United States as well. There was an event in 2018 that was somewhat overlooked,
where a company that is responsible for essentially data analysis and data collection
for pipeline operations was compromised in such a way that it impacted the ability of that company
to perform its role in managing pipeline related data for managing inventory, tracking shipments,
billing, etc. And the result was, is that the pipeline system while it could physically operate,
because operations were reliant on the data aggregation and analysis of the this particular
software suite, that operations were significantly impaired for a period of time,
while the organization worked to recover from that incident. So the ERP software
in question enables pipeline transfer operations by tracking resources and billing seems like
fairly mundane things. But if you can't adequately bill for material that's flowing through your
pipeline network, or you can't even track the amount of material flowing through the network,
it's really hard to operate in an accurate or sustainable fashion. And by disabling or
modifying that ERP, which does not appear to have been the case in this attack, but is a possibility
that may have occurred as a result of this sort of an internal attack. So the ERP software
an attacker could significantly reduce the operational effectiveness and integrity of
the system in question, such that even though the physical pipeline network would still be
okay, you could still pump gas, oil, water, whatever it is, chemicals that are flowing
through the pipeline network, from a sort of logical perspective, removing the ERP functionality
results in inability to adequately control and monitor that process so that you could no longer
operate the pipeline, even though the physical pipeline integrity is still there. So there's one
key component, which is also network facing as opposed to air gapped or isolated, happens to be
a Achilles heel for potentially impacting the entire pipeline system. Finally, last example,
thank you for bearing with me so far. Also in the United States at the end of 2019, we had another
incident impacting pipelines, where ransomware by impacting the IT environment linked to a pipeline
operator resulted in that pipeline having to shut down for a period of time. Because even though
again, the pipeline itself was not impacted directly by this event whatsoever, the ability to
gain visibility into an operational control over the pipeline was inhibited by losing IT based
assets. So again, we're having a physical impact, the loss of pipeline operations, in such a way
that then resulted in further follow on disruption, not just to the pipeline itself, but to all of
those consumers of the resources move through that pipeline, because kind of like we've talked
about earlier in terms of things like inventory minimization, and an emphasis on just in time
operations, most often when it comes to things like pipeline networks, you don't necessarily have
large surpluses or large inventories of whatever is flowing through that pipeline, but instead
are relying on just in time or continuous operations in order to continue natural gas,
electricity, general chemical plant, manufacturing, etc. In the case of something like this event,
where we could use ransomware in order to remove IT visibility over a pipeline network to a pipeline
shutdown, we can basically disrupt the pipeline without ever physically impacting
the operation of the pipeline itself such that we can undermine the entire system and then lead to
physical process, maybe not disruption outright, but certainly process interruption that can root
in the lack of ability or the inability of downstream customers to operate anymore,
all as the result of something that's purely IT focused without having any
bit of ICS magical understanding or whatnot whatsoever. Okay, so lots of examples,
lots of possibilities here. What does this mean? Well, for defenders, that means that
we're very comfortable defending or monitoring IT networks, we're very comfortable pen testing
these networks or performing risk calculations for these networks. But the thing is, is that
network defense, as we typically apply it, is usually blind to or agnostic to the actual business
processes or organizational principles that the network itself exists to operate. Adversaries,
however, are really only focused at the end of the day of delivering some sort of effect.
And the network major means to an end for the adversary, and rather, their ultimate goal is
trying to achieve some disruption or dislocation for the underlying organization, whatever it is
that the organization does generate value. Because we look at the attacker mindset, adversaries have
goals, their goal is to make money, their goal is to disrupt Ukraine, their goal is to disrupt the
United States or Poland or something else along those lines. Well, the nature of that goal,
shutting down the electricity, manipulating the financial system or whatnot, is going to determine
what type of attack. Cyber attacks just happen to be fairly easy, easy to execute remotely,
fairly cheaply to perform instead of throwing bombs at someone and whatnot. And so they're
just really a means to achieve whatever it is the attacker wants out of this entire process.
By identifying the routes to the goals or the various touch points to achieve these goals,
shutting down the electricity, shutting down a pipeline, manipulating election results, attackers
can then start figuring out, okay, based upon what I'm trying to achieve, what is the easiest,
simplest way of trying to do this and achieve some sense of mission success? Because ultimately,
attackers don't get judged on how complex or fancy their attack is. They really just get
judged on whether or not they achieve what they were instructed to do. That's what gets them
medals or allows them to pay out from a ransomware event and whatnot. Well, looking at this is that
network defense needs to adopt a mindset where we're not just focusing on the network as a value
in itself, but rather the network is just a means to an end. The network allows the organization to
continue producing value, generating value or not losing value for the organization. So if we
really want to start looking at the various dependencies that play out in terms of how
organizations are built currently, as defenders, we need to adopt a mindset that's similar to
attackers where the network is just a very accessible or easily manipulated touch point
that attackers can use in order to cause further on value disruption. And by adopting this mindset
of value defense for the organization, we can gain greater perspective of what are the important
things within our own networks that we need to defend and what are the external dependencies
or the sort of unlooked for cascade of consequences that might exist from certain attack
vectors so that we don't get surprised by things such as like we saw in the 2014 case in Ukraine
where we could do our jobs quite well, but because of a forgotten or unlooked for external
dependency, such as relying on the media in order to broadcast results that attackers can use that
external dependency as a way to get around our own internal successes to still achieve or
potentially achieve their own goals. We need to start mapping through and understanding and
extending where we can either our preventative defense or at least building in mitigations and
resiliency to try and meet and overcome these sorts of scenarios. So really what we're looking
for here is a type of full scope defense where first we want to understand the organization
itself. Then we want to start mapping defense to the process and organizational dependencies within
our environments and build out detections, resilience, and recovery to match the possibilities
for disrupting key sources of value in our environment. So the very first step in all this,
and this might seem trivial, but it's pretty significant, is that we need to identify what
is it about the organizations we work in that generate value? Whether we are providing network
defense for a university, for a global manufacturer, or for a bank, what is it that allows our organization
to continue to function? This very simply could be monetary. How does the organization make or not
lose money and what are the sources of value generation within the environment? But that
extends a little bit further into sort of functional values, such as what processes
does the organization rely on in order to generate value? Based on that, we can then start mapping
out what are the sort of critical nodes necessary in order to ensure that processes remain functional.
This could be something like looking at the Backbone Swift software that allows for interbank
transfers, for example, that if that doesn't exist, the entire financial system grinds to a halt.
Maybe we want to make sure that we build in resiliency or some understanding for
how we ensure that the sort of plumbing between organizations does not get disrupted so that
we don't get essentially a functional kill on the business through something that we otherwise were
ignoring or not bothering to control. And lastly, and this is kind of interesting as well and
somewhat difficult to try and defend against, but very important to keep in mind,
there's also the question of reputation or optics. When it comes to disruptions, intrusions,
and other activities, what type of disruption can an organization actually withstand? Can we have
something like acceptable losses, or are there certain things that even any sort of intrusion,
any loss of data, or any disruption whatsoever results in too significant of a reputational hit
that we must avoid at all costs? So based on that, we could look at examples such as when
evaluating different resources within our networks. Not every resource is equivalently
valuable. So we certainly know that things like domain controllers are critically valuable
for the sake of network operations, but it may be that we also have servers or workstations in
our environment that are also fundamentally valued because they control fundamental aspects of the
business in such a fashion that if that workstation or that server is corrupted, disrupted, or data
from it is lost, we are undermining the ability of the organization to function properly such that
we need to defend that at all costs. Whereas some random workstation in accounting or HR, while we
don't want that to be compromised, if it gets hit with ransomware, it's fine because we can recover
that machine without negatively impacting the overall value proposition of the organization.
So really looking at a function-based or functional level of defense that is tied to different aspects
of where it is the organization generates and maintains value. Next, figure out how that
overlaps with the cybers. So what information systems map to those critical value sources?
You know, this can include things like where the design models are kept for a manufacturing
environment or where the trading algorithms are housed for a financial services company or where
the key intellectual property is located for any sort of research and development organization.
And then figuring out what IT capabilities are necessary in order to continue and facilitate
that value generation. Finally, then figure out does your defensive capability
and IT visibility extend to these critical assets? This is where the industrial control
perspective becomes quite handy because what we often see is that critical sources of organizational
value, like the actual production environments that enable a manufacturer to exist and to do
their jobs, lack the sort of visibility necessary to adequately defend and monitor those environments,
whereas different parts of the network that aren't really vital to the existence of the
organization, like all the computers in HR, for example, they're important, but if they go away,
the business can still function. If the plant floor network goes down though, production ceases,
the organization begins losing lots of money, yet we expend lots of effort on building up defense
for these non-vital networks. You know, they're still important, but they're not vital, while
ignoring some of these vital resources that if they were to get compromised or disrupted in some
fashion would lead to critical losses for the organization as a whole. So finally, this also
extends not just to preventative defense, but building out resiliency as well, because we can't
always be certain that we will stop every single attack. Setting that as a goal is not only
unrealistic, it is quite impossible, which means we must also build into the concept of operations
resiliency and recovery. This means not just the ability to restore a workstation, but also when
it comes to critical processes within our environment or critical business aspects,
can we not just restore a computer, but are we restoring information? Are we restoring
configurations and other such items? So that we not only bring up the logical asset, but also
bring up things to a known good, known level of integrity after an incident takes place.
Part of all this, so we're at ZivCon, this is where red beats blue, right? Well, that also
means that these concepts of trying to focus network defense around organizational value
and understanding process dependencies needs to be adequately tested and audited. And the best way
to do that is through testing these plans and trying to observe exactly how it is that we're
doing when it comes to trying to build out a organizationally specific, operationally resilient
defensive planning. So the way we can do this and doing this through an actual pen test is difficult,
but certainly things like tabletop exercises or walkthroughs of incident response and defensive
plans and doing a critical look at things like where our network visibility and where our network
defense is enabled can allow us to try and identify areas where we are weak or where we need to build
out greater amounts of detection and visibility. So we can take our defensive measures and our
recovery plans and run them against comprehensive attack scenarios that don't just look at,
hey, I can get domain admin, but rather attack scenarios that look for objectives like, hey,
I want to put your company out of business, or hey, I want to shut your organization down for
seven days or something along those lines. And how would I go about doing that? Not just what
networks would be breached, but what are the critical touch points I would need to compromise
or disable that would enable this sort of event. And this allows us to begin identifying gaps or
missed vectors as part of our existing defensive plans and building out a more holistic or greater
in scope defensive planning that can take into consideration these sorts of scenarios. So yes,
something very much like a purple team exercise that incorporates not just your IT personnel,
but also the individuals that are responsible for how it is your organization is generating value,
whether that's the manufacturing environment, the operations personnel responsible for how
the bank runs, et cetera, to try to identify what are those critical items that are necessary for
the organization to continue operating. Okay. So to close out, what are my future expectations
in this space? So I think this is a fascinating topic and it's not something that is typically
covered from a cyber perspective because it involves lots of understanding of business
environments and how IT networks overlap with more general operations. Well, the thing is,
is that we don't have a choice because attackers are getting smarter and bolder when it comes to
these sorts of operations that have been doing so going back at least through 2014 and are doing so
in a way as time has progressed from there to becoming more targeted, more disruptive,
and potentially outright damaging as we saw with the Abqaiq strike, such that organizational
defenses have no choice but to evolve with adversaries to meet these challenges and to
